components.copy:
## Know your objective

Before you adopt digital technologies into your business, ask yourself some simple questions to help you choose, purchase and implement the right solutions.  It’s important for you to plan and think about what you need for your business and how your business currently operates to get the most out of your new software.

components.copy:
Ask yourself the six questions below to get you started. 

### 1. What’s your goal? 
Think about your business goals and how new software can help you achieve them. Is it to increase sales or to spend less time on admin as your company grows?  

- What are your top priorities right now?  
- Is high staff turnover a problem? 
- Are you struggling to meet delivery deadlines?  

Think about when you want to achieve your goals by. 

When you're shortlisting products, analyse which one meets most of your requirements and will continue delivering benefits in three to five years. 

When talking to salespeople, ensure the benefits they are selling are right for your business.

### 2. What new software or adoption have you undertaken before? 

Ensure that you use the lessons learned from previous experience or if it's new to you, talk to someone who can tell you the challenges they had to overcome to be successful with digital adoption. 

- Have you tried to introduce similar software to your company in the past and it didn’t go as well as you had hoped?  
- What issues and barriers did you come across last time which you wouldn’t want to repeat? 

Once you know your priorities, you can start to find the suitable software your company needs.

### 3. What does success look like? 

Get opinions from your colleagues. For example, asking your team to complete an anonymous questionnaire giving their feedback.  Ensure they feel like they are a part of the journey and understand that they need to use the new tools for the technology to succeed. 

- Is your team keen to try new ways of working? Do they currently use software?  
- How you will introduce this new product to the business, will there be training sessions or a user guide?  
- What do you want to avoid as you implement the software?  
- What would make this project a success?

### 4. What’s your budget?

When purchasing new software, it's important to have a budget in mind so you don't overspend. 

- Work out your budget. Have you put aside enough funds if there are any extra expenses you haven’t thought about in your budget plan?  
- Can this investment happen straight away, or will it need to happen later? Do you need to find extra funding from outside the business? 

Think about your existing systems and how the new systems will integrate. Does it have to work for overseas operations?

image.name: Choosing.jpg
image.alternativeText: Involve your team early when introducing new software
image.caption: Involve your team early when introducing new software

components.copy:
### 5. Who’s involved, and who might be impacted? 

If you think you may need help making your new software a success, the following questions will help you determine what you need to do next. 

- Who will install the new software?  
- Will the software company support you or will you need to install the new technology yourself?  
- Will you need any help with training? 

- Is there a team of experts in your business who can champion the change and support employees who need more help?

### 6. Are there any dependencies? 

Think about what factors could impact the installation of your new software. The questions below will help you plan any obstacles you might face. 

- Will your new software need to be integrated into a system you already have?  
- Could integrating new software cause issues that might affect your ability to trade until they’re sorted?  
- Could integration decrease productivity in the short term if things don’t run smoothly?  
- Will you be introducing multiple new systems or services? 
- Plan how the new software will all work across your business; will you install the software all in one go, or in stages?

When installing new software, it's important to think about cyber security. Cyber security is how individuals and organisations reduce the risk of becoming victims of cyber attacks. It's about protecting our devices (smartphones, laptops, tablets and computers), the services we access and the personal information we store on these devices and online from unauthorised access, theft or damage. Protecting yourself and your business from cyber security risks can seem daunting but here are some [simple steps](/cyber-security) you can take to ensure you have the basics in place. You can also find more information on protecting yourself from cyber threats on the [National Cyber Security Centre website](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/cyberaware/home).

### Tell them what you need  

List your requirements and don't leave out any details. How well they listen to your specific needs is a good indicator of how helpful they might be after purchasing.

### Are they communicating clearly? 

  Are they using jargon to explain how their products meet your needs, which you're struggling to understand? Ask them to explain it more simply. If they can't, they could be hiding something or might be unsure how the software product will work for your business

### Does  the software sound too good?

Find out what their software can and can’t do for your business. Find out if there are ways their software it can be adapted to suit your business operations.

### Are they talking about business needs?

Software suppliers should have a good understanding of how your business or industry works. The right supplier will understand your business needs and how they can help you and your business.

### Is the software still in development?

Be aware if software features are still in development or coming soon. There's no guarantee that they will ever be available and the timing could impact on how long the software is available for and if it meets your needs.

### Do I need the extras? 

You may be asked if you are interested in purchasing software add-ons, but ask yourself: Do I need this? Will it bring any direct benefit to my business and can I afford it?

Once you have found software suppliers you're happy with, get a detailed quote from them.

Pricing can be confusing, so it's essential to understand what you're paying for.

When you’re thinking about your software budget, consider the following:

### Subscriptions

Most software is now sold on a subscription basis, or software as a service (SaaS), where you buy a monthly or annual licence.

Think about how long you will need these subscriptions for as they will be part of your ongoing costs.

### Yearly or monthly

Yearly or annual subscriptions usually work out cheaper, but if you only want to try out the software for a short period don't commit yourself to a one-year contract.

### Fee per user 

Depending on the software you're buying, a licence fee per user is the most common option, also known as 'per server' or 'per web application'. Work out how many members of your team will need a licence, so you know the total cost.

### Am I locked in? 

Check if you'll be charged if you change your mind. Do you have a grace period where you can cancel your contract? Did you buy it online? Check if there’s a trial period.

### Package deals 

Licences may include support packages and extra features. Make sure you read the fine print and only pay for what you need.

### Introductory offers 

You might be offered a discount on the first few months of a subscription, and that’s a great way to see if you like the product or not. You can then consider a lifetime subscription if you like the software.

### Basic vs premium

Basic versions have fewer features or options for customisation. Weigh up if this will do the job you need and what the costs or terms of the contract are if you upgrade to a premium version at a later date.

### Support and maintenance

If you don’t have an in-house IT support team and are likely to need support, check if this is included with the software licence. If so, does it offer support during out of office hours? How long are response times? Is help available seven days a week, and is it via phone, email or in-person?

What other support is included as standard? This could include:

- installation and configuration
- integration with other software or systems
- warranty
- user manuals
- user workshop

components.copy:
Karim Samani knows first-hand how badly your health can be compromised thanks to unhygienic IT equipment. It happened to him in 2017. Following his recovery, he took matters into his own hands and set up TechDisinfect within the commercial cleaning sector.
The qualified accountant from Manchester soon discovered, however, that spreadsheets alone couldn’t help him manage his client base or potential sales leads. He made the decision to find another solution. Karim says: ‘I felt the key to success for TechDisinfect - as with a lot of other small to medium-sized enterprises - was how I could manage effective communication with my clients.’

textblocks.copy: I wanted to understand how I could collect data from my sales leads and clients, while analysing calls, emails and meetings all in one place

components.copy: ‘In the beginning, keeping people’s information in one place was really difficult. Coming from a financial background, I loved spreadsheets, but they didn’t give me the kind of control I needed.’

It was during an encounter with an adviser from a Growth Hub, set up to offer information and advice to local businesses, that the benefits of adopting CRM software became apparent.
‘I wanted to understand how I could collect data from my sales leads and clients, while analysing calls, emails and meetings all in one place, to help secure sales. The adviser told me all about Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software and how it could help with that and more,’ explains Karim.'

textblocks.copy: Coming from a financial background, I loved spreadsheets, but they didn’t give me the kind of control I needed

components.copy:
In order to select suitable CRM software, Karim began testing the various functions different packages had to offer. Complementing the software he already had in place was essential.
‘I needed to understand what was going to work best with my current website, and what functionality I was able to add without breaking it,’ he explains.

image.name: TechDisinfect-170620-037_new.jpg
image.caption: Techdisinfect member cleaning a monitor

components.copy: ‘I decided to do a lot of testing. For example, I’d send dummy emails to myself to see what happened when they hit my inbox and I also filled in contact forms on our website.‘Because I was new to the software, I wanted to make sure that what I chose was right for me.’

One of the main selling points for the CRM software Karim chose was its ease of use and the support the software company provided. For Karim, this included telephone advice and online tutorials.
‘In the beginning, it was a bit tricky to understand the full capability and functionality of the CRM that we chose. Gradually, the more we used it, the more we began to understand it better,’ Karim says.
It wasn’t long after adoption that Karim realised the benefits CRM software brought to his business, including the option of segmented email campaigns to ensure he reached the right client base.

image.name: IMG_0183_new.jpg
image.caption: Techdisinfect member cleaning a keyboard in an office

components.copy: ‘Before, when someone contacted us via the online form on our website, all we’d get is an email notification. Now, the CRM software automatically analyses the information contained within the contact form, including; the type of customer they are, where they’re located and even what device they’re using,’ says Karim. ‘It then automatically files it away for us in the right place, so we can target those same people with specific email campaigns.’

Another driving force in choosing the right Digital Accounting software was adopting something that could hold client information reliably and securely, while also ensuring it enabled him to stay up to date with credit control. ‘I’d seen a lot of people struggling with that,’ Darren explains. ‘I knew friends in other trade industries who used more traditional methods and their credit control was awful.’

components.subheader: What is Help to Grow: Digital?
components.copy:
Help to Grow: Digital is a UK-wide government-backed scheme that aims to help you choose, buy and adopt digital technologies that will help you grow your business.  The Help to Grow: Digital scheme offers your business:  - **Free, impartial advice and guidance** about what digital technology is best suited to your business and how it can boost your business’ performance  - **Targeted financial support, if your business is eligible**, worth up to £5,000 towards the costs of buying approved digital technologies. 

What support can I access through Help to Grow: Digital?

The Help to Grow: Digital website provides you with free, impartial advice, guidance, and tools, to explore the huge potential digital technology has to help your business to grow. Designed with industry and independent experts, we will keep adding to the   advice and guidance available here. Take the first step and get help to:  - identify the digital technology needs of your business  - make informed decisions about which software products best meet those needs  - successfully incorporate these products into your business  Financial help to buy digital technology Later this year, if you are eligible, you will be able to claim a discount of up to 50% on the costs of buying approved software, worth up to £5,000, on the Help to Grow: Digital website. 
Discounts are initially expected to be available for software that helps your business to:  - build customer relationships and increase sales  - make the most of selling online  - manage accounts and finances digitally

### Business eligibility The financial discount towards the costs of buying approved software will be available to businesses that meet all of the following criteria: - have between 5 and 249 employees - are registered in the UK Companies House or are a registered society listed on the Financial Conduct Authority’s Mutuals Register  - have been trading for more than 12 months prior to the date application   - are purchasing the approved software product for the first time. Businesses will not be permitted to purchase an approved software product that they already own or have an active subscription to Eligible businesses will only receive one discount towards the purchase of one approved software product. Full business eligibility criteria and terms of conditions for the financial discount will be published later this year.
### How can Help to Grow: Digital help my business? The right digital technology can take your business to the next level and boost your performance.  Digital technology can help you:  - **organise your business activities more efficiently** including automatically generating invoices and helping to track spend  - **improve your ability to reach new customers** though data collection that helps you understand their wants and needs  - **make your work smarter and more flexible** by using automation to reduce the time spent on admin, and storing information in one central, accessible location  - **knowledge and training** - from knowing which software is best suited to the business, to finding the expertise to , install and support it - **funding** - investing in new technology can be a huge financial commitment for small businesses, and often one they would like help with  Many businesses feel cost and knowledge are barriers to adopting new digital technologies:  This is where Help to Grow: Digital comes in. Through its expert guidance and targeted financial support, we can help you overcome these challenges and harness the power of digital technology, so you’ll be spending less time on those draining admin tasks, and more time increasing sales.  Help to Grow: Digital can help open doors to new opportunities and give you the time and space you need to grow your business. 

How can I find out more about Help to Grow: Digital?

If you have an enquiry about the Help to Grow: Digital scheme, please email us at [sme.helptogrow@beis.gov.uk](mailto:sme.helptogrow@beis.gov.uk) When you email us, please provide:   - your name   - email address   - company name and address    And tell us if your email relates to:  - technical support with the Help to Grow: Digital website or ‘Register Your Interest’ online form  - Help to Grow: Digital financial discounts on software   - Help to Grow: Digital advice and guidance on software 

How can I apply to provide digital technologies under Help to Grow: Digital?

  If you are a software vendor and want to provide digital technologies under the Help to Grow: Digital scheme in the future, please [contact us](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/help-to-grow-digital-apply-to-become-a-vendor).   Applications for wave 1 of the scheme are now closed and further information on future waves of the scheme will be published in due course.

**SAVE TIME ON THE EVERYDAY TASKS TO DRIVE BUSINESS**

 

Changing how you manage your essential data like financial information and customer contact details give a quick win for saving you time and reducing the opportunity for human error. 

 

[In our survey](https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1010738/LSBS_2020_SME_Employers.pdf) we found that around 30% of SMEs are still using spreadsheets and paper-based records for their accounts. This presents a huge risk for incorrectly filed accounts and is incredibly time consuming when you need to collate receipts, invoices and manually check payment has been received. 

 
Other ways automation can help save time is by using Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software to store, track and review customer habits. 

 

Giving you better data to manage your business and your customers’ experience, it means details are entered once and stored centrally so team members can access what they need without having to chase anyone else in the team for information. 


**UNDERSTAND YOUR CUSTOMERS**


Knowing the wants and needs of your customers is vital for retaining clients and attracting new ones.

Using paper and spreadsheet based methods to spot trends, especially over a longer period of time, is incredibly time consuming and at risk of human error. 

Swapping spreadsheets for CRM could provide the opportunity to track and cross-reference your trends automatically, by clicking checkboxes for what you want to see.  

 

This can help you track: 

 

- **Regularity of spend** – covering a date range or by customer type 
- **Sale value** – understanding average spend could help plan future promotions 
- **Purchase type** – great data for understanding stock levels and expanding your ranges 

 

If you’re thinking about loyalty plans, seasonal promotions and where to drive product development, this is vital data.

**BOOST SALES BY REACHING MORE PEOPLE**

When SME trading only happened offline, competing with bigger brands was next to impossible. It took big budgets for sustained exposure. Now, people are choosing to shop online and buy from independent traders more, the opportunities are vast. 

 

The creation of online marketplaces and tools for marketing and promotion have levelled the playing field. Environments like social media platforms let you readily examine what your competitors are doing, and how well your shared target customers respond to different methods of advertising and products. 

 

Combined with easier access to professional looking designs for your logos and a website, suddenly a smart, targeted brand presence that reaches more of your ideal customer is in grabbing distance.

### Initial set-up costs

Think about the initial costs you’ll need to pay for including:

-  Licence fees
-  Installation
-  Training

-  Project management
-  Consultancy and paid-for advice

Ongoing costs may include:

- Software licence renewals and upgrades
- Cloud service subscriptions
- Hardware leasing
- Upgrades
- Maintenance

### Monthly or yearly subscriptions 

Monthly subscriptions are a great way to trial a product to see if you like it, and you can cancel the following month if it’s not right for you.

Yearly subscriptions are often cheaper, but you may be tied to the same product for a year. However, you might be able to cancel the contract early if you pay a fee.Calculate your ongoing business costs by working out how much it would cost to purchase and run new technology alongside your existing subscriptions.

components.copy:
In 2010, after starting to sell local artisan foods in her Wiltshire shop, Surinder Hothi-Bellamy became frustrated at the lack of authentic Indian food sold locally. It was then the idea for Pure Punjabi was born.
Surinder and her daughter Safia started by selling traditional, non-perishable items including dried ingredients and spices at local markets and food shows before creating their first website.
They soon realised creating their own online space wasn’t without its problems.

‘We learned early on things don’t just happen organically when you start to sell online,’ Safia explains. 

‘We’d set up the website, [purepunjabi.co.uk](http:purepunjabi.co.uk), and someone told us they’d Googled us and couldn’t find us. 

‘We just assumed it all happened organically. We thought if you had a website and someone searched for Pure Punjabi, it would just appear.’

Like many businesses, Surinder and Safia didn’t have too much technical knowledge or money to invest into increasing Pure Punjabi’s online presence. 

Surinder says: ‘We were self-funded and didn’t have the tech know-how, so we tried to learn as we went along, which makes things difficult for anybody starting in eCommerce.’ 

Having understood the importance of being found online, Surinder and Safia knew that adopting eCommerce software was going to play an essential role in helping to grow their business.

components.copy:

‘Without the traction, or any history or record of sales behind us, we had to find a solution - that solution was eCommerce.’

In 2013, Surinder attended a four-day business course, which helped her find out more about eCommerce and the potential it had to help the family business to grow.

‘It was at this point I realised that eCommerce software was a must-have and not a nice-to-have in order to help Pure Punjabi to grow. 

‘He advised us to change from our existing website provider and we switched to another platform that had eCommerce functionality built into it.’

‘The eCommerce platform offered us advice on which plugins we needed, not only for our shopfront, but also anti-hacking tools to protect our site,’ says Surinder. 

As their business began to grow and Surinder and Safia carried on hosting live cookery events, they spotted an opportunity and made the decision to start selling food kits online.

Safia explains: ‘We basically did pop-up events but realised some people were unable to attend, so mum said, “Why don’t we do a workshop in a bag?” 

‘We started providing people with all the dried ingredients and spices online, all the specialist ingredients – the same sort of stuff your grandmother would use.’ 

The pair also started offering hospitality services for weddings and large corporate events, enlisting more staff to help.

‘Our workshops were gone, our events were gone,’ Surinder recalls. 

‘We’d normally do one big national show a year and quite a few regionals, but we realised everything was gone and we were left with the meal kits.’

components.copy:
‘We sat down very quickly and thought about what our customers usually asked us; we’ve always been led by feedback, and a lot of questions were based on what food goes with what.’ 

Using their eCommerce software, Surinder and Safia began pairing different food types together on their website’s shopfront, called them dinner kits and sent an email out to their customer list. ‘We saw a 1200 per cent increase in sales within the space of three weeks,’ Safai explains. 

The team also invited people who purchased their dinner kits to online cookalongs in order to bring people together during lockdown.

Safia says ‘We suddenly had people from Ireland, LA and Madrid coming together to cook with us online,’ Safia says. 

‘Our customer support was so strong, and because we’d set up everything up digitally and we had an eCommerce website that was functioning, it was simple for customers to click and order. That was it. It was done.’

### Reaping the benefits

Since adopting eCommerce software, Pure Punjabi has gone on to receive a number of Good Taste awards and has also been named one of the top Indian cookery courses in the UK by Olive food magazine. 

The company has also been able to reach new audiences and sell to customers anywhere in the world without physical boundaries. 

‘eCommerce has also made the customer journey easier for visitors to our site. We can constantly tweak it if any feedback’s received, including moving what’s on our shopfront and improving the search functionality for the things we sell,’ Surinder says.

It's about protecting your devices (smartphones, laptops, tablets, computers), the services that you use (emails, your website, payment portals), and data (personal, business) from unauthorised access, theft or damage.

components.copy:
Cyber security is essential for all businesses and needn’t be daunting. Following our guidance can significantly reduce the chances of you and your business becoming a victims of cyber-crime. 

You can also read more about keeping your small business safe online in the [National Cyber Security Centre’s Small Business Guide](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/small-business-guide). 

Operating online – simply using email or having a website – creates the risk of cyber attack. If you want to protect your business, then understanding and implementing basic cyber security measures is critical.

No matter what size your business is, you should regularly back up your data and make sure it can be restored. This will help to ensure the business can still function if there's a fire, flood, physical damage, theft or [ransomware](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/guidance/mitigating-malware-and-ransomware-attacks) attack.

### What to consider when backing up your data

#### What do you need to back up?

You should regularly back up the data your business needs to run. This could include documents, photos, emails, contacts, or calendars.  

#### Store your backed up data on a separate device

This can be on a USB stick, a separate drive or computer. Restrict access to these data backup devices so that they are:

- Not accessible by staff
- Not permanently connected (either physically or over a local network) to the device holding the original information. A local network is a collection of devices connected in one physical location, 
   such as a building, office, or home.

A useful rule for backups is that you should have three copies of your data, on two separate devices, one of which is offsite (not in the same place as your main copy). 

If you store your backup data in a different location and a fire or theft occurs, you will be able to recover your critical data and get back to work.

### Cloud solutions

Using cloud storage, where a service provider stores your data on their infrastructure (which is a collection of hardware and software) means your information is physically separate from your location. Service providers can supply your organisation with data storage and web services without you needing to invest in expensive hardware. Most providers offer small businesses a limited amount of storage space for free and larger storage capacity for minimal costs. 

Read the National Cyber Security Centre’s (NCSC) [cloud security guidance](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/cloud-security?referrer=es215) collection alongside their [Small Business Guide Step 1](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/small-business-guide/backing-your-data). To help you decide if a cloud service is secure enough to handle your data. 

#### Back up your data as part of your everyday business tasks

Backing up data is not as time-consuming as you may think. Most network or cloud storage solutions can be configured to back up your data automatically. This saves you time and ensures you have the latest versions of your files. You should set automated backup periods that work for your business. 

Most off-the-shelf backup solutions are easy to set up and affordable. When choosing a solution, consider how much data you need to back up and how quickly you need to access this data following an incident.

Mobile devices – from smartphones to laptops – are essential to modern business. Even phones and tablets can be as powerful as desktop computers, and need even more protection as they often leave the safety of the workplace. 


### Keep your device secure by:


- Switching on password, PIN or biometric (e.g. fingerprint or face recognition) protection. A strong PIN or password to prevent criminals from accessing data 
- Ensuring lost or stolen devices can be tracked, locked or wiped 
- Regularly updating your devices’ operating system. Tell your staff how important these updates are, as they contain critical security updates to protect the device 
- Encrypting your device. For laptops and PCs, use an encryption product (such as BitLocker for Windows). Most modern devices have encryption built in, but encryption may still need to be 
   turned on and configured, so check you have set it up. 
- Keeping your apps up to date. Like the operating systems on your organisation's devices, all the applications you have installed should also be updated regularly  
- Not connecting to unknown Wi-Fi Hotspots. If you connect to these, someone could access what you're working on and personal login details

### Use a strong and separate password that’s different from your email account and social media account


Your most important, key accounts will include email, banking apps, and your mobile devices. You should use strong passwords for these accounts which are not shared with any other account you use. 

Email is particularly important, as if a hacker gets into your email account, they could: 

- Reset your other account passwords 
- Access information you saved about yourself or your business

components.subheader: Tips for creating and protecting your passwords
components.copy:
### Ensure you use password protection Set a screen lock password, PIN or other authentication method (such as fingerprint or face unlock) on your devices.
### Use two-factor authentication (2FA) for important accounts 2FA (also known as multi-factor authentication (MFA) requires two different methods to prove your identity before you can use a service. One factor is usually a password, while the second is often a code sent to your mobile phone or registered email address, or generated from your bank's card reader. #### Change default password - One of the most common mistakes is not changing the manufacturers' default passwords on smartphones, laptops and other equipment. Ensure you change all default passwords before distributing devices to staff #### Avoid predictable passwords - Avoid using number or letter sequences such as 12345, or guessable passwords such as your pet’s name. Instead try using [three random words](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/blog-post/the-logic-behind-three-random-words?referrer=es215) which is an excellent way to create a strong, unique password that you will remember #### Use a password generator - Online password generators create and store strong passwords for you, and make it possible to have a different password for every account

A phishing attack is when scammers send fake emails to thousands of people asking them to click on a link or provide sensitive information. Phishing emails are becoming harder to spot, but some things to look out for are: 

- **Authority** - Is the message claiming to be from someone official? For example, your bank, doctor, a solicitor, or a government department. Criminals often pretend to be important people or 
  organisations to trick you into doing what they want.
- **Urgency** - Are you told you have a limited time to respond (such as 'within 24 hours' or 'immediately')? Criminals often threaten you with fines or other negative consequences. 
- **Emotion** - Does the message make you panic, fearful, hopeful or curious? Criminals often use threatening language, make false claims of support, or tease you into wanting to find out more. 
- **Scarcity** - Is the message offering something in short supply, like concert tickets, money or a cure for medical conditions? Fear of missing out on a good deal or opportunity can make you 
  respond quickly.
- **Current events** - Are you expecting to see a message like this? Criminals often exploit current news stories, big events or specific times of year (like tax reporting) to make their scam seem more 
  relevant to you.


Look out for unusual requests from people you work with – for example making a payment to a different account or by a different method. If in doubt, contact the person using details you already have for them (not those given in the email) and ask if the request is genuine. 

If you have received an email which you’re not quite sure about, don't use the links or contact details in the email, forward it to the[ Suspicious Email Reporting Service (SERs)](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/information/report-suspicious-emails?referrer=es215) using [report@phishing.gov.uk](mailto:report@phishing.gov.uk)

It’s a series of questions that have been developed to lead you through the main parts of the Cyber Essentials requirements and will start you on your journey towards becoming Cyber Essentials certified. components.header: Accessibility statement for Help to Grow: Digital
components.copy:
This accessibility statement applies to [learn-to-grow-your-business.service.gov.uk](https://[learn-to-grow-your-business.service.gov.uk) 

This website is run by the Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy (BEIS). We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, that means you should be able to:

- change colours, contrast levels and fonts 
- zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen 
- navigate most of the website using just a keyboard 
- navigate most of the website using speech recognition software 
- listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver) 

We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand. 

[AbilityNet ](https://mcmw.abilitynet.org.uk/) has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:

- Alternative text attributes are not always meaningful.
- Some form inputs do not have accessible names.
- Some text may be difficult to read due to a lack of contrast.
- A visible tab focus indicator is not always consistent in its presentation.
- Some user interface components have the same name which may cause problems for speech recognition users.
- Empty links are present that do not have an accessible name.
- Some decorative images may still contain descriptive alt attributes
- A correctly formed heading structure is not present to facilitate navigation across the site.
- A ‘Skip to main content’ link or similar is currently not present on the site.
- All page content is not identified with appropriate ARIA landmarks.
- Some documents are in PDF format and are not accessible.

Email: [sme.helptogrow@beis.gov.uk](mailto:sme.helptogrow@beis.gov.uk) ## Accessing information in a different format Email us if you need information in a different format, such as a printed copy of any of the information contained on this website. In your email, include: - the web address (URL) of the content - your email address and name - the format you need We’ll consider your request and get back to you with an initial response. ## Reporting accessibility problems with this website If you find any problems that are not listed on this page or you think we’re not meeting the accessibility requirements, [email us](mailto:me.helptogrow@beis.gov.uk) or call [0207 215 5000](tel:02072155000). ## Enforcement procedure The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, [Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)](https://www.equalityadvisoryservice.com/). ## Technical information about this website’s accessibility The Government Digital Service is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018. ### Compliance status This website has been tested compliant with the [WCAG2.1 AA](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG2AA-Conformance.html) standard. ## Non-accessible content The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons. ### Non-compliance with the accessibility regulations Images on some pages do not always have suitable image descriptions. Users of assistive technologies may not have access to information conveyed in these images. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.1.1 (Non-text Content). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Decorative images on the site do not contain alternative attributes. This may result in file names being announced to screen reader users. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.1.1 (Non-text Content). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Headings that contain no content are present, and some content looks like headings but is not marked up as such. This can make it difficult for keyboard and screen reader users to navigate the page. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Regions of the pages are not identified with appropriate landmarks. Keyboard users may have difficulty navigating the pages, and screen reader users will not be able to identify all areas of a page. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.1 (Info and Relationships). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Some text is present that does not have a sufficient contrast ratio against the page background. Users with low vision may have difficulty reading text that does not contrast with its background. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.3 (Contrast (Minimum)). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Zooming the ‘Resources’ page to 400% with a browser width of 1280px results in a two-dimensional scroll to view content in full. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.10 (Reflow). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 A correctly formed heading structure is not present to facilitate navigation across the site. This includes missing heading levels and empty headings with no content. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.1 (Bypass Blocks). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 A ‘Skip to main content’ link or similar is currently not present on the site to allow users to bypass repeated navigational components across the pages. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.1 (Bypass Blocks). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Some page titles are not descriptive or reflective of the page content. Users may have difficulty identifying the page contents by its title. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.2 (Page Titled). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Multiple ‘Read the article’ links do not announce additional information relating to their location via screen reader. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.4 (Link Purpose (In Context)). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Empty links that contain no text are present. The function or purpose of the link will not be presented to keyboard and screen reader users. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.4 (Link Purpose (In Context)). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 The focus indicator sometimes reverts to the default browser focus indicator when tabbing to links across the site. This can make it difficult for keyboard only users to keep a track of the elements currently in focus. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.7 (Focus Visible). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 HTML validation errors are present across the pages which may impact users of assistive technologies when navigating the site. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 4.1.1 (Parsing). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 When navigating the pages with either VoiceOver or JAWS screen readers enabled, unexpected content such as divider elements are focused on and announced to the user. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21 Form controls such as checkboxes, radio buttons, and text input fields do not have corresponding labels. The function or purpose of the form controls will not be presented to screen reader users. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value). We plan to resolve this by: 31/10/21

## Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations **PDFs and other documents**
Some of our PDFs and Word documents are essential to providing our services. For example, we have PDFs with information on how users can access our services, and forms published as Word documents. There’s lots of information on different tech products out there, and taking a structured approach with a shopping list will help compare and make the right decision based on your business needs. This will help you decide which is the right product for your business.

components.subheader: Why do I need a shopping list?
components.copy:
Creating a shopping list will help you to focus on the features and functionality of the software your business needs. It's also a simple and quick way to help shortlist products and suppliers. 
 
Our checklist will help you find the right software, understand your business requirements and determine where your new software will fit into your company.

## Shortlisting software products

Comparison sites can help you shortlist products, by allowing you to compare products by cost, support, features and compatibility.


Once you have shortlisted some software products and suppliers, take a look through our checklist to make sure you choose the right software for your business.

- **Ask for a demo. Many software providers will offer demos or trials** so you can see how the product works and decide if it's right for your business. 
- **Double-check the features**. Some products don’t have all the features listed on comparison websites. 
- **[Make sure you’ve set your budget](/calculating-your-budget)** and checked costs (both initial and ongoing) to make sure you can afford the software and it offers the right return or benefit for your business 
- **Read the reviews**. Check they are genuine and coming from an independent source. 



[(Download the create your shopping list PDF(215KB)](https://htg-dev-strapi-app.azurewebsites.net/uploads/Creating_your_shopping_list_a372eb0e9a.pdf)

## Which software features does your business need?
 
Our features checklist  covers the most common questions  to help you decide which software you need.  

Not all the questions are about technology - some are there to help you understand your business and where your new software will fit in.

### What do you need the software to do? 


- Do you want to improve your existing ways of working? 
- What does the new product need to have that your current solution doesn’t?

### How does your business operate? 

- Do you work across multiple locations? Do you need software to support this?
- Do you need the software to work across multiple languages, currencies, tax regimes or regulatory environments? 
- Will you need helpdesk support? 

### How flexible are your requirements? 

- Are there any requirements that are non-negotiable? 
- Would you be open to increasing your budget for certain features or add-ons? If so, what are these? What level of customer service are you looking for?

### Do you want off-the-shelf, customised or bespoke software? 

- Off-the-shelf software may be cheaper, but you may have to change some of your processes. Is that something you would be happy doing?
- Would you prefer to pay more for software which is tailored to your business? Would you be willing to spend time and money maintaining and upgrading custom-built software?

### Can you develop an in-house solution? 
 
- Do you have in-house specialists who can develop and maintain custom-built software for you?  
- Would you be able to maintain this if your in-house specialists leave?

### Is there a reason why standard software might not work for you?

- Is there something unique about your business?  
- Do other businesses in your industry use specific software? 
- Are there any special circumstances in which your staff will use the software?

components.copy:
### What security needs do you and your clients have?

- Does your business have advanced security needs?
-  Do any of your clients need advanced security, or for data to be handled in a certain way? For example, do you do any work in the defence sector, or the care sector?

### Are there industry or sector-specific regulations you need to comply with?

- Do you need to choose software which is approved by a regulatory body, or that complies with particular standards?

### What will the software need to integrate with?


-  Will you add other software or systems in the future to integrate with?

### Is this new software replacing old software?

- What did you like and dislike about your old software?
- Do you need to transfer data from an old system to the new one?  Have you looked into the process for doing this?

### What infrastructure do you already have in place?

-  Is the new software compatible with different  devices and operating systems, for example, Windows, Apple or Android? 
-  If you’re choosing cloud-based software, do you have a good broadband connection?

image.name: collaberation.jpg
image.alternativeText: Get feedback on new tech from your team
image.caption: Get feedback on new tech from your team

components.copy:
### What software would be beneficial for your staff?

-  How might the software impact day-to-day roles?
-  Will staff need to transition to new ways of working?
-  What impact, if any, might the new software have on the culture of your organisation? You may want to involve your staff in the selection of the new software to ensure you choose one that 
   suits those using it.

### What software is appropriate for your clients, suppliers or partners?

-  How might new software change their experience of working with you?
-  Do your clients or partners have particular needs to consider?
-  Does this software need to be compatible with any software that your clients, suppliers or other partners use?

### Will you need help setting up and implementing the software?

- Will the software supplier offer support to implement the software into your business?
- What technical support will you need to implement the software? Who can provide this and how much will it cost?
- Do you have the capability and capacity to support the software internally?
- If you need external support, what level of service do you need?
- If your new software requires new technical expertise, do you have this in-house or will you have to bring this in?

### What training will your team need?


- Who can deliver training to your staff to ensure they get the most out of the new software? Could someone in your business do this?

### What are your growth ambitions, and how will the new software make this happen?

-  Are increases in usage likely? For example, will you need more licences? Can the software product support this?
- What changes in requirements and functionality are likely as you grow?


### How might your growth plans impact the ongoing support you might need?

-  Are your required service levels likely to change? Will the provider be able to deliver this?
- What level of customer service are you looking for?

#### [What’s your budget?](/calculating-your-budget)

-  How much can you spend up front? Can you afford ongoing costs?
-  How much will it cost to set-up the new software in your operations and integrate with your existing IT systems and business processes.
-  How much can you spend on ongoing support such as training, updates and maintenance?

### What’s your contingency plan?

-  Do you have a buffer in your budget for unexpected expenses?
-  How much benefit will the software have to deliver to cover its costs?
- How soon do you need to see these benefits?
-  What’s your exit strategy if it doesn’t deliver?
